fields.description: When I click Pull, I would like to be able to do all of the things in Fetch at the same time (fetch from all remotes, prune old branches, fetch all tags).
fields.summary: Pull and Fetch in one

fields.description:
Commit message should go to the top of the screen. Makes much more sense. The "main action", like after pressing the Commit button, should not go to the bottom of the screen. In UX-land, this is bad design, as a general rule.

Please put the commit message near the top.
fields.summary: Commit message at the top!!

fields.description:
Press the commit button and you'll go to the commit "mode". Then, press the commit button again and absolutely nothing happens. I'd expect it to perform the commit, but it doesn't. I have to press a different commit button near the bottom-right of the screen.

Being experienced with SourceTree, I still sometimes make this mistake, and I shouldn't have to. I don't want to have to think about this kind of stuff.

The Cancel button in commit mode also doesn't make a lot of sense. It's the same as not pressing the commit button, right? It's not like you're cancelling out of a process you're stuck in. Can be removed.
fields.summary: Commit button pressed while committing should commit

fields.description:
Please put the File Status, Log/History, Search tabs to the top. Makes more sense UX-wise.

This is already the case for the Mac version (which is weird in its own respect) and it feels much more natural. My mouse doesn't "live" at the bottom of my screen when flying around buttons near to top of the screen. Also, the bottom is generally a place for a statusbar... And there is one at the bottom-right, which makes the tabs on the same line all the weirder.

Place put tabs at the top, either like on the Mac version, or in another way. But tabs at the bottom is just too weird.
fields.summary: Tabs at the bottom -> top

fields.description:
When I go and perform a commit, Sourcetree automatiically switches to the File Status tab. This is fine, because that's where the commit is going to take place. But after this, either by comitting or by cancelling, it doesn't go back to where it came from (in my case, I "live" on the Log/History tab).

So every time after committing, I have to go all the way to the very bottom of my screen (for which I'll create a separate issue) to select the right tab again.

This needs to change. Please make SourceTree return to where it came from when it needs to go to a different tab automatically, after the performed action (like a commit) is done.
fields.summary: After commit, go back to the Log/History tab

fields.description:
Normally when selecting a file (in the "Log / History" tab, when an unstaged file is selected) the right pane shows hunks of changes. Sometimes this pane is completely empty. I have to select another file and then back to the original one to see any changes. As if it doesn't update itself for some reason, or something.

This is especially annoying when there's only one unstaged file and no staged files. I have to select a different commit (and then back) to make it display hunks of changes :(

This bug is not reproducible by request. I can't make it happen, I just happen to notice this problem form time to time.
fields.summary: Right pane shows nothing

fields.description:
Multiselect unstaged files sometimes doesn't work. In such cases, shift+click on a file just doesn't do anything at all. I have to click on another file and then click on the previous and then shift+click to multiselect would work.

This is not reproducible on-demand. I just happen to notice this problem every now and then. I have no idea why or when.
fields.summary: Multiselect unstaged sometimes doesn't work
Crash when selecting all unstaged files by single tick box and clicking "commit"
SourceTree uses wrong sequence to pull large files from Mercurial repo

fields.description:
Upon commiting some changes to my repository, I was graced by your wonderfully polite error screen.

I have attached the logging. I hope it helps.

On a side note, I'm running SourceTree from a VirtualBox machine.

Kind regards,
Mike Zuidhoek
fields.summary: Crash on commiting

fields.description:
Cannot compose commit message in Japanese with IME.

Strange UI feedback:
 * Types all ascii-latin1 characters are OK.
 * Try ascii-latin1 and compose with Japanese-IME, cannot enable IME.
 * Copy Japanese character from another text editor, then paste this character in commit window, it works right after that, IME too.

* This problem come from version 1.6.1, 1.4.* are no problem.
fields.summary: Cannot compose commit message in Japanese with IME.

fields.description:
Too many changed files in one commit, SourceTree hangs up show preview this commit.

# Auto-Generated source codes about 3000 files ;-)
fields.summary: Hang up SourceTree by show many files commit.

fields.description: Typo on button "Зафиксировать" (russian translation) in commit window
fields.summary: Typo in button name

fields.description: I has some network issues when i closed the application
fields.summary: error when closing application

fields.description:
Given SourceTree is running
And I edited code in Visual Studio
When I return to SourceTree to commit changes
Then SourceTree crashes after it has refreshed repository log
fields.summary: Crash when returning to SourceTree

fields.description: I was just trying to push a project.
fields.summary: Unsuccessful push
SourceTree does not start because some repo is missing/invalid

fields.description:
When scrolling through files to commit with files checked, ghost checks appear and disappear as the list is scrolled.

To replicate: 
Check one or more files in the middle of a list (files, staged files, ...)
Scroll up and down with the mouse
Checkmarks should appear briefly and fade out
fields.summary: Persistent checkmarks when scrolling in checkboxed list

fields.description: My hg commits cannot be pushed to my repository server because of a permission error. However, SourceTree crashes right after.
fields.summary: Crash when push fails on permission error using mercurial

fields.description:
Pointing mouse to the list of commit message history does not highlight the message.
It is better if the currently selected message is highlighted.
Using Windows 7 Pro.
fields.summary: Pointing mouse to the list of commit message history does not highlight the message

fields.description: If I try to push a repository containing subrepositories while the subrepositories have unpushed content I get a nice dialog showing I've to push the subrepo's first. If I then 'Open' the subrepo from the dialog and push the build I get a very nice (but emberassing) crash window. :P
fields.summary: Crash if subrepo is not yet pushed to server

fields.description:
Right now, I can only select a file in a commit and choose the options "Log Selected" or "Blame Selected". But often the file I want to log may not be in the current commit, and I may not know any of the commits that touched it.

This becomes a hassle to use log and blame, as then I have to hunt for the commit, look it up in the commit history, then hunt for the file, then choose the Log Selected or Blame Selected option.

Please enhance the Log and Blame to support entering custom file names, in a search box, so that I can view the log or blame for that file without knowing or finding beforehand any commit that touched it.

1) When Log Selected and Blame Selected options are normally disabled, they could instead be transformed into Log and Blame options, which bring up a text input, where I can enter a file name or names. Upon clicking OK, the log or blame should be shown for it.

2) The windows showing the log and blame should also have a search text box, or some way to change the file for which the log or blame is being shown (like a button to bring up the same text input dialog in (1)).

Wild card search will be nice, but at least an exact search is a basic necessity.
fields.summary: Log and Blame for any file (with filename entered as text)

fields.description:
Dialog going off screen, I have to just press Enter which I know represents OK.

See screenshot: http://sc-cdn.scaleengine.net/i/b07f0a3ae7e4e32ab1aea9193796b0111.png
fields.summary: 'Confirm Remove?' dialog too large - expanding off screen

fields.description: I usually want to merge using the --squash option but now I need to do that through the command line. Please add this option to the merge dialog.
fields.summary: Support git merge --squash command

fields.description:
It will be nice if the Archive feature (right-click a commit, click Archive) could have a checkbox "Modified files only" to make an archive containing only the files *changed or added* in that commit.

If possible, the commit selection could be improved to select the two endpoints of a range of commits (from commit A to commit B), so that all the modified files in the range can be archived (latest versions where two or more commits modify the same file).
fields.summary: Archive feature to have option to archive modified files only

fields.description:
When I browse to my Bitbucket repo and use the Clone in Sourcetree Button (Selecting HTTPS as the protocol) the information that appears in Sourcetree error message is
https://git@bitbucket.org/ddurkee0/app_py_tk_powermeter.git
The error description is...  'The protocol in the address is not valid.'

I think it should be:
https://ddurkee0@bitbucket.org/ddurkee0/app_py_tk_powermeter.git
If I Clone from Source tree and paste in the address everything is fine. I think this is minor but when I was trying to learn how to use GIT, Bitbucket and Sourcet tree, I think this could have caused me to become very confused. I din't think this could actually be a bug. 
I have done very similar tasks on my Github account and theres seemed to work.
fields.summary: Clone in Sourcetree from BitBucket website uses git@bitbucket ..

fields.description:
I did a search in one git-repository, then changed tab to another repository, did a pull and switched tab again to the first repository. SourceTree crashed.

This happens often when I change tabs and the tab which I'm changing to has the search tab active.
fields.summary: Crash when switching repository tabs

fields.description:
We use Gitflow with SourceTree and Stash, and after having Pull Requests merged in Stash, I end up with a lot of merged branches still in SourceTree.

I would like to be able to right-click a branch-folder and select "Delete merged branches" and have branches that have already been merged into master or development branch be deleted.
fields.summary: "Delete merged branches" feature on right-click of branch-folder

fields.description: I had a csv open in Excel, tried to "Remove" the csv from my working copy, but it seemed like it was simply not working (when in reality window was preventing the file from being modified by another source while it was open in excel). Very minor issue but felt worth reporting.
fields.summary: There is no alert/error if windows cannot delete a file when doing a "Remove" from Working Copy

fields.description:
The diff view and log history is getting reset at a time period corresponding to the check default remotes setting.  I see no reason why this needs to happen.  While viewing file differences, it appears as though the diff view turns blank and the first file within the log history is selected at some time interval, even though the file never changed on disk.  Also, even if a file changed, I don't see how that matters because I am looking at a commit that occurred in the past.  When looking at the diff view for a change that occurred within the past I don't see how any refresh setting should affect the diff view.

Take a look at this thread which includes a screen shot within my recent post.  Basically, with the setting enabled the diff view is totally unusable for me.  I have no choice but to disable the option or do all diffs within an external application.
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/184935/answers/11451803
fields.summary: Check default remotes setting causes unexpected reset of diff view while looking at changes

fields.description:
Quite frequently clicking on certain merge commits in the log in one of my projects causes SourceTree to completely hang. It sits with a spinning icon on the pane where the commit details (id, author, message, etc) should appear. There are no git background processes running.

I can terminate SourceTree and restart it and it will reliably happen again.

The UI thread has gone into either an infinite loop or a very long running operation, taking 100% of one of my processors. I've attached a stack trace.
fields.summary: Hang viewing certain merge commits

fields.description:
Upon opening SourceTree today it prompted me to register for free as the trial was over.  I clicked the button and got this odd error message.  (see attachment)

It seems that your registration server response is malformed.

I can't register due to this, and thus can't use SourceTree as closing the dialog closes the program.

*Workaround*:

Register your license on my.atlassian.com from your browser and import it to SourceTree, using the option import license from file in SourceTree.

Receiving this on startup of SourceTree, then I can not perform any action such as Commit, Push or Pull on a Mercurial. I believe it's the issue with node_modules folder being too long, https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/6960

Please see screenshot:
http://sc-cdn.scaleengine.net/i/e4d7c044bfd26032de50545bd95bbc28.png

fields.summary: crash when clicking on certain items in the log view

fields.description:
After upgrading from SourceTree 1.6.8 to 1.6.11 (intermediate versions not tested) the program causes problems when working with a Stash Git repository that is accessed via HTTPS or SSH. The behaviour was consistently observed on 6 different machines using Windows 7 and 8. 

Any interaction with the repository, such as simply selecting the master branch causes SourceTree to freeze for varying amounts of time. The Task Manager shows full CPU utilization of one core and abnormal RAM usage (growing more than tenfold). For an example see the attached screenshots which show the state of the frozen GUI and task manager after double clicking "master".

The Stash server is running in the local network but is accessed via its public address. HTTPS is configured using a Wildcard SSL certificate from GoDaddy, the root CA bundle had to be added to the clients via "git config --global http.sslCAInfo [path/to/ca_bundle.crt]". Without this checking out the repository would produce the git error message "SSL Error: unable to get local issuer certificate".
fields.summary: Window freezes when working with Stash Git repo over HTTPS/SSH after update to 1.6.11

fields.description:
For building purposes we create an orphan build branch which basiclly mirrors a corresponding branch, ie;
- master vs. build/master
- some-branch vs. build/some-branch

The branches under build/* are orphan branches. We're doing this via CLI like so;
{code}if build branch exists then
  git clone source/ build/
  git checkout --orphan build/master build/
else
  git branch build/master origin/build/master
  git clone -b build/master source/ build/
endif{code}

The sourcetree GUI sometimes crashes when selecting/viewing a commit from an orphan branch.

The changesets in build/* can get pretty large :)
fields.summary: Sourcetree crashes with orphan branch

fields.description:
When opening SourceTree and selecting the branches view for a very specific project (other projects do not do that), the SourceTree UI completely freezes, CPU goes high and never finishes (waited more than 12 hours).

Since this is a project we just moved from SVN to GIT, the initial commit has a very large number of files (> 7K). I think the problem arises when SourceTree tries to show all files for this commit (see picture attached).

Repository source is hosted on BitBucket. A collegue using the MAC version does not have this problem.

Tested each version since 1.5.2 and I am sure that the problem began at 1.6.9.
fields.summary: Branches view freezes UI and takes a full CPU

Minimized it again cpu shot back up,restarted the program, minimized -> High cpu. Also tried restarting computer same thing happens.

fields.description:
When there are pending files, SourceTree tries to load the entire file so it can show me a preview.
When those files are large, this leads to very high memory usage (out of proportion with the file size) and SourceTree becomes unusable. The UI will not respond and I cannot do anything until I track down and delete the files that cause the problem. 

For example, Visual Studio crashed and ReSharper created copies of its settings files that got corrupted. These files were 10 MB each. When I tried to start up SourceTree after rebooting, it took forever to start and consumed 2.5 GB of memory. After I got rid of those files, memory usage went down to 300 MB. So two files of 10 MB each led to additional memory usage of over 2 GB.
fields.summary: Performance problems when there are large pending files

fields.summary: SourceTree won't start

fields.description:
Hello,

I have a big problem. So I have a project that is located on bitbucket. This project is 30MB big.

The problem now is, that SourceTree is downloading this project very slow. SourceTree is downloading the project with 6Kb/s to 116KB/s. This means for me, that I need to download the files manuall by clicking the download repository button on bitbucket, because that is really faster then waiting for SourceTree.

Then after some time of trying to download the project, SourceTree gives me every time this error: 
RCP failed: result=18, HTTP code = 200
ffatal: The remote end hung up unexpectedly
atal: early EOF
fatal: index-pack failed

If I then got then the files on a different way then using SourceTree, SourceTree is really slow. Without that big projects SourceTree isn't that slow and I need not to wait about 10 to 20 seconds for one click.

I hope that this can be fixed. ;)

fields.description:
h3.Steps to reproduce
# Create a tag '1.0' for a commit in the branch master
# Create a tag '2.0' for another commit in the branch test
# Make sure that "All Branches" option is selected in "Log/File History" tab
# Selecting the tag in the sidebar will auto select the commit with the tag
# Checkout to master branch
# Select the option "Current Branch" instead of "All Branches"
# Select the tag '1.0' in the sidebar will auto select the commit with tag '1.0'
# Select the tag '2.0' in the sidebar (No response)

SourceTree should have a popup message that the selected tag does not exist in the Current Branch.
fields.summary: Clicking on a tag in the sidebar should have a message that the tag does not exist in the current branch

fields.description:
**How i got to this repeatable error:**

1) had main branch
2) created a hotfix branch, committed it with wrong text
3) rebased hotfix with master (everything o.k.) - a commit immediately above the master was my single hotfix commit with a wrong description
4) sow i had to change text, so I selected the commit node on the master (my hotfix is a child of this commit)
5) started to rebase interactively
6) did double click on the text
7) messagebox to enter text was showed
8) either pushed enter or ok button and source tree crashed.

With 4 Git repos open, while seraching for authors in all 4 of them Sourcetree crashed.

See log with recent event for details.

fields.summary: Closed all cloning repositories

fields.description: did not clone repository
fields.summary: did not clone repository

fields.description:
[EDIT:  I've updated an rewritten a bulk of this description as I have found a 100% repo and a simpler repro steps than my first repo on the first experience of the crash]

I believe I have steps for a 100% (5 out of 5) repro steps for crashing SourceTree Win32 client when selecting cancel on the 'Checking subreposities...' dialog shown when pushing a repo that has a subrepo with pending pushes. (see attached jpg screenshot of the dialog I refer)

I have setup a bitbucket mercurial repo with nested mercurial sub-repos.  Just to a depth of 3.  Say my sub-repo hierachy looks like this:

A
+- B
.   +- C

I made an actual change to subrepo C and committed it locally.  This made subrepo B's state info for C change, so I commited locally on subrepo B.  This in turn made 'the root' repo A's state info for B change, so I commited locally on subrepo A also.

Then for an experiment I tried to push changes to bitbucket starting with root repo A.  SourceTree displayed the Checking subrepositories... dialog to let me know that I had pending pushes on subrepos.  I've found that if I click the Cancel button on this dialog that SourceTree appears to crash 100%.

This dialog sits spinning for several second getting ready (communicating with remote bitbucket perhaps or checking local repo state).  If I click Cancel at any time it will crash.  It also crashes regardless of whether I generate this dialog from attempting to push root repo A or push subrepo B.
fields.summary: client crashes if I push cancel on Checking subrepositories dialog

fields.description: I cannot anymore add changes to tracked files to index. In UI both the "Add" button and "Add" option in right-click menu are disabled. This only affects changes to already tracked files - I'm still able to add new files.
fields.summary: Cannot add changes (add functionalities are disabled in UI)

fields.description: Can you please add an option to turn off auto generating diff? If there is a larger commit with a lot of files (let's say a major update), it just slows down the whole process. Especially on slower computers. Just add an option to turn off automatic generating diff on commit click. Maybe add that option for each project?
fields.summary: Slow Diff

fields.description:
SmartGit has a very nice feature: displaying "lost heads" in the log view.

This is one feature that so far I found I miss when trialling SourceTree and it would be great to see this feature added.

Screenshots from SmartGit attached.
fields.summary: Show "Lost Heads" in log view

fields.description:
When using the interactive rebase the application crashes.

Looking at git status (from the command line), I see that an interactive rebase has been started, and git is "...currently editing a commit while rebasing branch 'rebase-tmp' on '7645e2a'"

I have attached the log files immediately after the crash.
fields.summary: SoureTree (for windows) crashed when performing an interactive rebase

fields.description:
I've got a butt-load of repositories now - and finding them can take longer than i wish. It would be really handy if there was a sort of search box - toolbar thingy above the tree that would filter the tree based on the search critiera. So as i type in my repo name/folder name the tree is reduced so i can quickly find my the repo i'm after.

Oh, you're going to do that in the next release? You're awesome ;) (lol)
fields.summary: Add search feature to tree pane

fields.description:
After update to 1.6.11 SourceTree will crash on start ala Windows MB "Program has stopped working and needs to close" Also going back to older version does not help anymore. 1.6.0 seems to work.

{quote}

fields.summary: Illegal characters in path.

fields.description: It would be great if there was an option to ingore whitespace changes in compare. Hopefully with a small button on top of the window to quickly toggle on/off.
fields.summary: Allow ignoring whitespace changes in compare

fields.description:
Using TortoiseHg, when I shelve a set of changes, I can update to a different branch, and unshelve them there. In the fresh work directory, only the specified set of changes is then applied.
In SourceTree, this doesn't work: when I shelve a set of changes, then update to a different branch, it appears to (attempt to) merge the entire branch the shelved changes came from, and only then does it apply the shelved changes!
This makes shelving quite useless, if I can't apply shelved items whenever I want.

Could you please support the official shelve plugin?  I've tried disabling SourceTree's shelve plugin, and use the 'regular' one, but that errors out because of unrecognized options.

If I have to switch to TortoiseHg to properly use shelving, then it won't take long until I stop using SourceTree at all... :-\
fields.summary: Unshelving in a different branch merges the entire branch.

fields.description: Every update force sourcetree to be unpinned from the taskbar, in all windows versions.  Anything that can be done about this, frustrating, and doesn't happen with any other program that I've observed.
fields.summary: Program unpinned from Taskbar.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
- Clone any git repository and specify clone depth greater than zero (shallow clone)
- Open the cloned repository Log/History view
- Scroll down to the very first commit and click on it
- Observer SourceTree application hang and runaway memory leak

This may be caused by the fact that in a shallow clone the very first commit in a repository refers to a parent commit which has not been fetched from the server.
fields.summary: Clicking on the first commit in a shallow clone repository causes a hang

fields.description:
Whenever I try to edit a commit on the rebase window, I get a "rebase --abort" right after I leave the screen.

Doing it in console works - but if i'd like console, i wouldn't need SourceTree :D
fields.summary: Interactively rebase always aborting - again in 1.6.4 and also in 1.6.11

fields.description:
As it currently stands, I see a number of issues with the repository list.

The first problem I have is that I often can't find the repository I'm looking for. The list of repositories I have in there is simply too long and there is no way to search for a specific one.
The result is that I often assume that I simply haven't added the repository yet, so I add it. SourceTree allows you to have the same repository in the list multiple times, so it allows it, even if I might just have overlooked it.
Now I have the same repository in the list multiple times, the list is even longer and I have an even harder time finding a specific repository the next time.

This problem also pairs very badly with SRCTREEWIN-2296.

I don't see the need to have the repository bookmarks in the first place. Why not just provide a treeview for the local filesystem and make it clear when a folder is a repository. Kinda like when you browse a folder hierarchy in IDEA, and it shows you which folder contains a valid project.

I feel like direct filesystem access, for repository selection, could vastly improve the workflow when working with a large number of repositories. 

Also, please allow me to close tabs by using the middle mouse button ;)
fields.summary: Improve UX for people who use many repositories

fields.description: I use GIT-TF plugin for getting code from TFS Server. The total amount of content there is very big (about 1Gb). After GIT-TF clone command I have one single git commit and the SourceTree hangs up to read the information of this commit and memory raises dramatically.
fields.summary: Hangs up if size of content is about 1Gb in one commit

fields.description:
Both e-git (Elipse) and TortoiseGit has an option to squash commits from GUI when merge a branch. Using SourceTree I'm forced to enter the terminal and write e.g. "git merge --squash MyBranch".

It would be preferable if there was an option to tick (check box) if a squash should be done when merge, using the Graphical User Interface.
fields.summary: Merge squash option from user interface

fields.description:
Every time there is an update, I have to go through the whole "setup" process once again (Next > Next > Next > Finish). This is a PITA for those of us who have auto-update notifications enabled and *want* it to be enabled (to ensure we have the latest and greatest SourceTree version ever!).

Usually, most software will only require you to go through the set-up process once on the first ever install (or when installing again after an uninstall). Updates happen seamlessly from then on, with minimal or no user intervention. I believe you can also achieve this by adding a silent option to the installer, which can be called by the updater. With the silent option, the installer would perform all steps automatically in the background, simply reporting progress to the updater.

*Minimal intervention:* An update is available. Would you like to download and install it? [Yes] Downloading... Installing... Installed! Restarting SourceTree... Enjoy!

*No user intervention:* An update has been downloaded, and will be installed the next time you start SourceTree. To install now, [Restart SourceTree].
fields.summary: Fully automate update installation (don't put us through the setup process)

fields.description: For any (git) command, when Show Full Output is checked (I have mine on by default) and output is larger than the max container size, the scroll position stays at top rather than auto-scrolling down to show most recent text as one would normally expect. fields.summary: Show Full Output doesn't scroll with text

fields.description:
Working on some branch and having uncommited changes results in some kind of linear history, like the following, while "u" designates uncommited changes.
{noformat}
u
|
o <-topic
|
o <-master
{noformat}
If the only action is deletion the history will look like

{noformat}
u   o <- topic
 \ /
  o <- master
{noformat}

If the deletions are staged the history will turn into the first version. It seems solely to be a display Problem. After a commit, everything looks like expected.

~~~~~~~ transcript (git bash Windows with sourcetree open) ~~~~~~~
git init displayproblem
cd displayproblem/
touch file
git add --all && git commit -m "first"
git checkout -b topic
touch file2
git add --all && git commit -m "second"
rm file
fields.summary: SourceTree displays "wrong" history for uncommited changes

fields.description:
I click Repository>Interactive Rebase.
Then click one commit record in the list and then OK (even without changing commit name).
Then SourceTree crashes.
fields.summary: Could not rebase a commit via "Interactive rebase"

fields.description:
Every time I open Source Tree a console window opens asking for my SSH key pass phrase. Since I'm not using such a pass phrase I just need to hit enter.

I suggest to add another check box to Options->General->SSH Client Configuration named "Do not ask for pass phase"

this can load to authentication errors if the user defined a pass phase when the box is checked. So this has to be checked (and the user has to informed)

as an alternative to the check box an input field to specify the pass phrase would work, too. This his to accept an empty phase!
But this solution would require to store the pass phrase some how what is a security issue.

Please think about it ;)

Thanks!
fields.summary: Add a setting to not check SSH pass phrase

fields.description:
I have one specific Git repository here which is terribly slow when using SourceTree 1.6.11 but behaves perfectly fine when using 1.5.2. On 1.6 it's actually not possible to switch or create branches.

This effect is reproducible across three different machines.
The repo is hosted using Stash 3.3.1 our clients are Windows 8.1, we tried with system (1.9.4) and embedded Git.

Which information I can provide you with to help solving this problem?

The repository does have no untracked files and has two tags, three branches.
fields.summary: SourceTree 1.6.11 terribly slow on one Git repository while 1.5.2.0

fields.description:
It would be great if we could have checkboxes or some other means to toggle show/hide of individual branches in the log/history (and graph) rather than just having the "current branch" vs "all branches" plus the "Show Remotes" checkbox being on or off.

Our company workflow involves a lot of remotes and seeing them all in the graph becomes cumbersome, but we do still want to see some remotes (e.g. origin) regularly, and usually we want to look at only one remote every now and then.
fields.summary: show/hide branches individually, rather than current vs all + remote or not

fields.summary: Sourcetree is not listed as a product for doing searches on the atlassian site

fields.description:
I'm seeing this crash when trying to update a submodule within a newly cloned Git repo. The steps I'm using to reproduce are:

# Open SourceTree
# Double-click the associated repository from the left hand repo browser treeview
# From the resulting repository tab; drill down to the submodule in the "Submodules" treeview
# Double click the submodule to update it
# The resulting update dialog states that the "server's host key is not cached in the registry", I then see a dialog asking me to accept the server's key
# Click "Yes" to retry
# At this point the application crashes with an ArgumentNullException

The stack trace I'm seeing is:

{code}
System.dll!System.Text.RegularExpressions.Regex.Matches(string input)	Unknown
SourceTree.exe!SourceTree.Utils.RepoProcess.CheckServerKeyRejectionsAfterFinish() Line 1060	C#
SourceTree.exe!SourceTree.Utils.RepoProcess.RelaunchIfAuthenticationError() Line 947	C#
SourceTree.exe!SourceTree.Utils.RepoProcess.DoCompletionFunctions() Line 587	C#
System.dll!System.Diagnostics.Process.RaiseOnExited()	Unknown
mscorlib.dll!System.Threading.ExecutionContext.RunInternal(System.Threading.ExecutionContext executionContext, System.Threading.ContextCallback callback, object state, bool preserveSyncCtx) Line 581	C#
mscorlib.dll!System.Threading.ExecutionContext.Run(System.Threading.ExecutionContext executionContext, System.Threading.ContextCallback callback, object state, bool preserveSyncCtx) Line 530	C#
mscorlib.dll!System.Threading._ThreadPoolWaitOrTimerCallback.PerformWaitOrTimerCallback(object state, bool timedOut) Line 1351	C#
{code}

I've attached a video of the problem occurring.
fields.summary: Crash When Accepting Server Key for Submodule
